Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S140. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: Monday June 3- Sat. July 27.

subject: FREN
title: Intermediate&Advanced FrenchII
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Paris. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed to perfect students' skills in understanding spoken and written French and in speaking and writing. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for nonacademic use of French. Priority is given to Yale students. Prerequisite: FREN 120, 121 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with FREN S130. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: Monday June 3- Sat. July 27.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Language Practice II
description: Offered in Paris, France. An advanced language course intended to improve students' comprehension of spoken and written French as well as their speaking and writing skills. Excursions to museums, movies, and theaters complement the reading of modern fiction and nonfiction texts. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 140, 145, or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.

subject: FREN
title: Advanced Culture&Conversation
description: Offered in Paris, France. Intensive oral practice for advanced students. An introduction to contemporary French culture and current events while sharing day-to-day life with Parisians. In small groups, students conduct surveys and interviews, melding the techniques of ethnography and photojournalism. Classroom activities include students' presentation of their findings, discussions and debates based on readings of newspapers and other periodicals, films, songs, stories, and clips from French television. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board in Paris, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Prerequisite: after FREN 150, 151, or equivalent proficiency. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.

subject: FREN
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of  twelfth-  and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: July 6 - August 10.

subject: FREN
title: Belle Epoque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey d'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6

subject: GLBL
title: Cause&EffctInSocialSciResearch
long_title: Cause and Effect in Social Science Research
description: Offered online. Methods used in the social sciences to make inferences about causality and to explain causal relations, including experiments, quantitative and qualitative methods, case studies, and fieldwork. Defining causation; methods for causal attribution; strengths and limitations of real-world research designs; practicalities and logistics of doing research; conceptualization and measurement. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: GLBL
title: CLOSED TO FURTHER ENROLLMENTS
description: The mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: GLBL
title: IntroHumanRightsTheory&Prctice
long_title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: GLBL
title: Society&Politicsof NorthAfrica
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counterterrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships being current international concerns. This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the twenty-first century. Students will meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German I
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S140. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: GMAN
title: Intermediate German II
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Berlin. An intensive, content-based language course that teaches linguistic skills through a variety of literary and nonfiction texts and film, with special emphasis on the culture and history of Berlin. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Berlin, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with GMAN S130. Prerequisite: GMAN 120 or equivalent. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: GREK
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Beginning Greek: The Elements of Greek Grammar
description: Introduction to ancient Greek. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for GREK S120. No prior knowledge of Greek assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: GREK
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Beginning Greek: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
description: Continuation of GREK S110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Greek authors. The sequence GREK S110, S120 prepares for GREK 131 or 141.  Prerequisite: GREK S110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: HIST
title: CANCELLED
description: Introduction to the study and writing of history, focusing on how African Americans fought for civil rights throughout the twentieth century. The civil rights movement placed in its historical context; African American freedom struggles placed in the larger narrative of U.S. history. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HIST
title: History of American West
description: The history of westward expansion and of the places west of the Mississippi River, as told through the people who saw it, experienced it, and made it happen. Beginning in the colonial era and concluding in the present day, with an emphasis on the nineteenth and twentieth centuries and international comparisons. Research will include the use of materials held at the Beinecke. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HIST
title: CANCELLED
description: The history of slavery from the seventeenth-century development of racial slavery in the Americas through contemporary forms of enslavement and human trafficking. Theories on the origins of slavery; definitions of slavery; the slave societies of the Caribbean and North America; the transatlantic slave trade; nineteenth-century abolitionism and emancipations; and the persistence of slavery in the twentieth century. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: HIST
title: Gender in Science and Medicine
description: Scientific and medical ideas about the natural world and the body have long been influenced by concepts of gender, even as expectations regarding gender have been shaped by scientific theories. Students will explore the historical relationship between gender and science, medicine, and technology in Western society, from the medieval and early modern period through to contemporary American debates. Students will analyze the relationship between science, medicine, and gender in order to gain historical insights and a critical perspective with regard to the structure of scientific and medical practice. Class visits to the Medical Historical Library and Peabody Museum expected. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HIST
title: Film, Video & American History
description: This course will examine the representation of American history on film and digital video, through the close analysis of American films from the beginning of the twentieth century to today. Topics will include: the Jazz Age, the Great Depression, World War II, the 1960s, Watergate, the Reagan Era, and post-9/11. Emphasis will be placed on the ways that films represent the historical moment from which they come. This course seeks to expand students' knowledge of the history of American film, culture, and society. Class screenings will feature such films as The Jazz Singer, It Happened One Night, The Best Years of Our Lives, Easy Rider, E.T., Do the Right Thing, and Traffic. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: HIST
title: Society&Politicsof NorthAfrica
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. This crossroads remains strategically important, with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships being current international concerns. This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the twenty-first century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.

subject: HIST
title: The Western World Since 1500
description: Survey of the political, social, economic, and cultural history of Europe since the sixteenth century. Special attention to theories and debates about the rise of the West. Agricultural, commercial, and industrial development; demographic change and social stratification; mass migration, trade, and globalization; religion and political ideology; monarchies, republics, and empires; revolutions, wars, and international orders; elite and popular cultures. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HIST
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, films, and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: HIST
title: CANCELLED
description: The destruction of European Jewry explored within the context of twentieth-century German and East European history. Conditions that led up to the Holocaust; regional variations of its perpetration. Contemporary interpretations of the Holocaust, including reasons they remain controversial. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HIST
title: History of Southeastern Europe
long_title: History and Culture of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and postcommunist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with SOCY S286. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,200. Course dates: June 30 - August 3.

subject: HIST
title: Japan's Modern Revolution
description: A survey of Japan's transformation over the course of the nineteenth century from an isolated, traditional society on the edge of northeast Asia to a modern imperial power. Aspects of political, social, and cultural history. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HIST
title: Empires of East Asia
description: Survey of the history of China, Japan, and Korea from the seventh century to the present. Focus on two separate empires: the Tang and Japanese. Attention to interactions among East Asian regions in the past and today. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: HLTH
title: Visual Approaches to Global He
description: The intersection of global health and visual media. Focus on international issues such as HIV, TB, human rights, and armed conflict. Film as a means for translating complex public health concepts into a format approachable by a general audience. Recommended preparation: a course in public health. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HSAR
title: IntroHistArt:Renaissnc-Present
long_title: Introduction to the History of Art: Renaissance tothe Present
description: A survey of Western art from the fifteenth century to the present. Introduction to both the masterpieces of artistic expression and the methods for defining and interpreting those works. Field trips to Yale museums and architectural walking tours complement the study of paintings, sculptures, architecture, and domestic and luxury arts. Readings include survey texts and original sources. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: HSAR
title: CANCELLED
description: Interacting with and writing about popular culture from an art-historical perspective. Focus on the intersections of art, music, and digital media design. Discussion of networks, virality, repetition, and memes, including their implications on a global stage. Case studies from music videos, smartphone and tablet apps, websites, and digital operating systems. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HSAR
title: Art and Science
description: The historical relationship between art and science in the West, from the Renaissance to the present. Case studies illustrate the similarities and differences between the way artists and scientists each model the world, in the studio and the laboratory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HSAR
title: Ten Works of Western Art
description: In-depth discussion of ten major works of Western art from the Renaissance to the modern era. Works selected both for their extraordinary qualities and for their capacity to represent a range of periods, places, media, themes, and functions. Includes visits to Yale's art museums to view corollary works of art; some attention to relevant poetry, literature, and film. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: HSAR
title: The Blockbuster and the Bomb
description: Exploration of the contemporary Hollywood film industry. Introduction to the close analysis of film sequences. Central components of a Hollywood production, such as script, director, star, and genre. Aspects of the industry, including production, distribution, and exhibition. Ingredients of blockbuster success; why some films fail catastrophically. Case studies pair current films with historical ones. Includes two screenings per week. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HSHM
title: Gender in Science and Medicine
description: Scientific and medical ideas about the natural world and the body have long been influenced by concepts of gender, even as expectations regarding gender have been shaped by scientific theories. Students will explore the historical relationship between gender and science, medicine, and technology in Western society, from the medieval and early modern period through to contemporary American debates. Students will analyze the relationship between science, medicine, and gender in order to gain historical insights and a critical perspective with regard to the structure of scientific and medical practice. Class visits to the Medical Historical Library and Peabody Museum expected. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HUMS
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HUMS
title: Belle Epoque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris. Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey d'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6

subject: HUMS
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Tragic Hero in Greek Drama
description: Introduction to the construction and performance of heroism in Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Defining the tragic hero; the tragic flaw; characterization and stagecraft; playwrights' responses to the Homeric hero; modern responses to Greek tragedy. Includes screenings of film adaptations of the plays. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HUMS
title: Bodies in Law and Literature
description: Representations of the human body in law and literature. The complex nature of how humans think about and give meaning to their bodies in relationship to themselves and to others. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HUMS
title: Italian Lang&Cinema in Tuscany
long_title: Italian Language and Cinema in Tuscany
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisa. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 22 - July 27.

subject: HUMS
title: CANCELLED
description: Modernity's fascination with the myth of Dionysus. Questions of agency, identity and community, and psychological integrity and the modern constitution of the self. Manifestations of Dionysus in literature, anthropology, and music; the Apollonian-Dionysiac dichotomy; twentieth-century variations of these themes in psychoanalysis, surrealism, and magical realism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HUMS
title: CANCELLED
description: Changes in the understanding of evil over the last century. Ways in which literature and film represent evil, assign a central role to it, and try to comprehend it, eliminate it, or lock it away as far and as long as possible. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: HUMS
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud's Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: HUMS
title: Rome
description: Offered in Rome, Italy. Designed as the logical complement and correlation to HUMS 444, this course will consider how Rome's contributions to Western thought are recorded in the very fabric of the city. Open to Yale students only. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Rome, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Prerequisite: HUMS 444. Enrollment limited, with preference to Humanities majors and juniors. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 2 - July 6.

subject: HUMS
title: StudioPracticePainting&Drawing
long_title: Studio Practice in Painting and Drawing
description: Offered in Auvillar, France. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students from liberal arts and fine arts backgrounds with or without prior experience. Studio Practice is an intensive study of painting and drawing focusing on the dynamics of the artist's studio practice of developing and constructing work. It is crafted for those who wish to study and experience the intimate process of personal idea imaging through the language of painting and drawing. Of great importance to the course is the development of strategies necessary for individual discovery, observation/analysis,and relational thinking. The residential program demands commitment, a strong work ethic and study within a 24/7 curriculum. All applicants should consult Robert Reed prior to completing the online application. Enrollment is limited to 15 participants. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Auvillar, room and board costs in France, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Interview required. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - June 29.

subject: HUMS
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum, and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of  twelfth and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: July 6 - August 10.

subject: IDRS
title: Ind Res in Sciences - 5A
description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a one- or two-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: IDRS
title: Ind Res in Sciences - 5B
description: Must be taken in New Haven. May be arranged for currently enrolled Yale students in Ecology and Evolutionary Biology; Engineering and Applied Science; Geology and Geophysics; Chemistry; Molecular Biophysics and Biochemistry; Molecular, Cellular, and Developmental Biology; Physics; or any other science department sponsoring such programs. These programs are especially useful for juniors in providing them with actual research experience prior to application to graduate or professional schools. Students wishing to enroll must complete the regular application for Yale Summer Session. In addition, students must submit written permission of (1) the faculty sponsor, who should also supply a one- or two-paragraph description of the research to be undertaken including the proposed starting and ending dates, (2) the Director of Summer Sciences, and (3) the director of undergraduate studies of the applicant's major department Students taking Independent Research for 1 credit must work 35 hours a week for five weeks (either Session A or B); for 2 credits students must work 35 hours a week for ten weeks (both Session A and B). Students may receive academic credit only if they are not being paid for doing research, but they may work for credit in one 5-week period and for pay in the other. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian I
description: Eight weeks in Grado (CRN: 30110),  or three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena (CRN: 30109). An intensive course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students will be able to choose a preference in the application of the Siena or Grado programs, but will be assigned to either as necessary because of seats available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Grado, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120 (in Grado CRN: 30113, in Siena CRN: 30112). For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian I
description: Eight weeks in Grado (CRN: 30110),  or three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena (CRN: 30109). An intensive course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students will be able to choose a preference in the application of the Siena or Grado programs, but will be assigned to either as necessary because of seats available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Grado, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S120 (in Grado CRN: 30113, in Siena CRN: 30112). For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: ITAL
title: Italian Lang&Cinema in Tuscany
long_title: Italian Language and Cinema in Tuscany
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. This five-week course combines beginning Italian with a course in English on Italian cinema focusing on Tuscany. Students will learn Italian through classes and full-immersion in the study-abroad experience (including a homestay), and will explore the representation of Tuscany through the screening and close analysis of films where the Tuscan setting has been elevated to the level of a primary thematic concern. Among the films to be considered are Room with a View, Night of the Shooting Stars, The First Beautiful Thing, Tea with Mussolini, The Sky Is Falling, Life Is Beautiful, Sandra, Mar nero, Good Morning Babylon, Fiorile, and the Florentine episode of Paisa. Students who wish to continue with Italian are required to take a placement test in order to place into ITAL 120. Students may petition for one HU credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 22 - July 27.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian ll
description: Eight weeks in Grado (CRN: 30113), or three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena (CRN: 30112). An intensive course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students will be able to choose a preference in the application of the Siena or Grado programs, but will be assigned to either as necessary because of seats available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Grado, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S110 (in Grado CRN: 30110, in Siena CRN: 30109). For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: ITAL
title: Elementary Italian ll
description: Eight weeks in Grado (CRN: 30113), or three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena (CRN: 30112). An intensive course designed for first-year Italian students, combining language study at the elementary level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Priority is given to Yale students. Students will be able to choose a preference in the application of the Siena or Grado programs, but will be assigned to either as necessary because of seats available. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Grado, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL S110 (in Grado CRN: 30110, in Siena CRN: 30109). For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian I
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Open to Yale students only. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL 140. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: ITAL
title: Intermediate Italian II
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in Siena. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course designed for second-year Italian students, combining language study at the intermediate level with an exploration of Italian literature, film, and culture. The second half of the course allows students to put their language skills into practice and provides for trips and cultural encounters in the Tuscany region. Open to Yale students only. Must be taken in conjunction with ITAL 130. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Prerequisite: ITAL 120 (Elementary Italian II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: ITAL
title: Decameron:CultureLang&Passions
long_title: Culture, Language, and Passions in Boccaccio's Decameron
description: Offered in Siena, Italy. The course will focus on close readings of a selection of short stories (novella) from the Decameron, the masterpiece of Giovanni Boccaccio. It will define the context of Boccaccio's narrative, placing it first of all in the cultural geography of Tuscany (Siena, Florence, Certaldo, his native town). Secondly, the discussion will explore Boccaccio's specific intellectual framework: the sense of nature; the place of human beings in the natural world; the value of medicine in the face of the Plague; the economy of the marketplace; the bourgeois ethos of selfishness, politics, tyranny, and power within the household (such as authority in the family, the place of women, sexuality). Using his native Tuscan vernacular, Boccaccio shaped his short stories and their frame to reveal the relationship between human passions, imagination, and literature. Taught entirely in Italian. Open to both Yale and non-Yale students. Prerequisite: ITAL 140, 145, or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Siena, room and board costs in Italy, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Course dates: June 22 - July 27.

subject: LAST
title: CANCELLED
description: Responses of Latin American thinkers to fundamental questions in social and political philosophy, from colonial times to the twentieth century. Issues surrounding rights and power, identity, race, culture, and political and economic development. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: LATN
title: The Elements of Latin Grammar
long_title: Beginning Latin: The Elements of Latin Grammar
description: Introduction to Latin. Emphasis on morphology and syntax within a structured program of readings and exercises. Prepares for LATN 120. No prior knowledge of Latin assumed. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: LATN
title: LatinGrammar Review & Readings
long_title: Beginning Latin: Review of Grammar and Selected Readings
description: Continuation of LATN 110. Emphasis on consolidating grammar and on readings from Latin authors. The sequence LATN 110, 120 prepares for 131 or 141. Prerequisite: LATN 110 or equivalent. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: LITR
title: Classical Mythologies
description: A study of the myths of Greek and Roman gods and heroes. The literary forms, historical contexts, and cultural uses of classical mythologies. Subsequent development and reception of these myths in various cultures and media from the Renaissance to the present. Analyses of these myths over the course of the past two centuries. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: LITR
title: Age of Cathedrals
description: Offered in Paris, France. Conducted in English. A study of the culture and monuments of the High Middle Ages in France, with visits to Notre-Dame de Paris, Saint Denis, Chartres, Sainte-Chapelle, Amiens, Beauvais, Rouen, Cluny Museum,  and discussion of accompanying historical, literary, and philosophical works by Abelard, Suger, Rutebeuf, Saint Bernard, Joinville, Thibault de Champagne, Pseudo-Dionysius, Marie de France, Jacques de Voragine, Guibert de Nogent, and the anonymous Song of Roland, Quest for the Holy Grail, fabliaux, and courtly lyric. Core consideration of Gothic architecture, urban and economic renewal, and intellectual and religious life of  twelfth and thirteenth-century France. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: July 6 - August 10.

subject: LITR
title: CANCELLED
description: Modernity's fascination with the myth of Dionysus. Questions of agency, identity and community, and psychological integrity and the modern constitution of the self. Manifestations of Dionysus in literature, anthropology, and music; the Apollonian-Dionysiac dichotomy; twentieth-century variations of these themes in psychoanalysis, surrealism, and magical realism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: LITR
title: Belle Epoque France
description: Offered in Paris, France. A study of important works of literature, painting, sculpture, architecture, music, and the decorative arts in turn-of-the-century France (1870-1914). This course will acquaint students with the principal literary and artistic forms, social trends, political movements, scientific theories, and technological innovations of the Belle Epoque, with visits to museums, architectural monuments, theater, and art nouveau cafes in Paris.  Principal authors: Zola, Gide, Proust, Bergson, Apollinaire, Maupassant, Mallarme, Colette, Alain-Fournier, Barbey d'Aurevilly, Simmel, Jarry, and Feydeau. Students choose HUMS, LITR, or FREN credit. Conducted in English. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Paris, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6

subject: LITR
title: The Logic of Dreams
description: The nature, history, and possible meanings of dream experience, with reference to Sigmund Freud'sÂ Interpretation of Dreams. Works from film and literature about dreams and dreaming, as well as major texts in dream theory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: LITR
title: CANCELLED
description: Changes in the understanding of evil over the last century. Ways in which literature and film represent evil, assign a central role to it, and try to comprehend it, eliminate it, or lock it away as far and as long as possible. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: LITR
title: CANCELLED
description: Survey of early twentieth-century German and Russian literature, philosophy, and visual arts. Focus on science fiction and visions of the future, including texts and images that depict Martians, evil robots, and the undead. Artistic audacity, uncertainty, and experimentation that dominated both avant-garde and mass cultures of the period. Readings and discussion in English. Click here for a video trailer for the course. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: MATH
title: CLOSED TO FURTHER ENROLLMENTS
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I
description: Limits, continuity, differentiation of elementary and transcendental functions, applications. No prior acquaintance with calculus is assumed. Pre-college students should enroll in this course only if they have a strong foundation in algebra and pre-calculus. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: MATH
title: CalcOfFunctionsOfOneVariableII
long_title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II
description: A continuation of MATH 112. The definite integral, fundamental theorem of calculus, techniques of integration, polar coordinates, Taylor series, applications. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: MATH
title: IntroFunctionsSeveralVariables
long_title: Introduction to Functions of Several Variables
description: Calculus of functions of several variables, with some linear algebra. Intended for students in the social sciences, especially those majoring in Economics. Prerequisite: one term of calculus of functions of one variable (MATH 112 or equivalent). Yale students may not take this course after MATH 120 or 222. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: MATH
title: Calc:FunctionsSeveralVariables
long_title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables
description: Analytic geometry in three dimensions, using vectors. Real-valued functions of two and three variables, partial derivatives, gradient and directional derivatives, level curves and surfaces, maxima and minima. Parametrized curves in space, motion in space, line integrals; applications. After MATH 115 or with permission of instructor. May not be taken after MATH 121. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: MCDB
title: Lab for Principles of MCDB
long_title: Laboratory for Principles of Molecular, Cellular and Developmental Biology
description: Experimental techniques and procedures in molecular and cell biology. Must be taken after BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or after BIOL S105. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,650. Session B: July 8 -  August 9.

subject: MCDB
title: Cell Biology
description: A comprehensive, interactive course in cell and molecular biology. Emphasis on principles of cell function and translational biomedical experiments. Prerequisite: BIOL 101 and BIOL 102, or BIOL S105, or permission of the instructor. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: MMES
title: CANCELLED
description: Global exploration of embodied ritual performance in Islam. Case studies range from ceremonies of the Mevlevi dervishes in Turkey to activist art in the context of U.S. detention and deportation of Muslims after 9/11. Development of practical skills in ethnographic research. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: MMES
title: Society&Politicsof NorthAfrica
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe. This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counterterrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships being current international concerns. This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the twenty-first century. Students will meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.

subject: MUSI
title: CANCELLED
long_title: Introduction to the Elements of Music
description: The fundamentals of musical language (notation, rhythm, scales, keys, melodies, and chords), including writing, analysis, singing, and dictation. Intended for students who have no music reading ability. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: MUSI
title: Listening to Classical Music
description: Offered online. Development of aural skills that lead to an understanding of Western music. The musical novice is introduced to the ways in which music is put together and is taught how to listen to a wide variety of musical styles, from Bach and Mozart, to Gregorian chant, to the blues. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: MUSI
title: Jazz and Race in America
description: Offered online. A study of the evolution of jazz, from its precursors in the music of Africa through its beginnings in New Orleans to its fusion with rock in the 1970s. Jazz's greatest artists and their styles are presented with selected music of each jazz period and a discussion of the racial and sociological factors surrounding the genre's development. While no extensive music theory background or formal instrumental experience is required, students who can read music will be best prepared to fulfill the listening and form identification assignments. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: NHTL
title: Intensive Nahuatl Lang&Culture
description: An intensive immersion course designed to familiarize students with modern and colonial Nahuatl. Beginning, intermediate, and advanced level students may apply. Formal class hours are complemented with individual language practice sessions and group cultural activities. Partial scholarships are available. Details on the Yale Latin American and Iberian Studies website, http://www.yale.edu/macmillan/lais/summer.html, or contact Jean Silk, jean.silk@yale.edu for further information. 3 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Program dates: June 24-August 2.
