subject: PHIL
title: Happiness
description: Historical and analytical inquiry into the meanings of happiness and their change over time. How new approaches to this topic in the social and natural sciences both complement and challenge time-honored philosophical and religious ideas. Whether happiness is a subjective and/or culturally relative idea; whether happiness should be a goal in life. The relationship of happiness to other valued goods such as meaning, freedom, pleasure, virtue, and justice. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PHIL
title: Introduction to Philosophy
description: Introduction to the history and methods of philosophical reflection and inquiry. Exploration of several perennial philosophical issues and the distinctive ways of addressing these issues through a close reading of historical texts and group discussion. Readings include selections from the works of Plato, Aristotle, Hume, Kant, Mill, and twentieth-century philosophers. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PHIL
title: Free Will, God, and Evil
description: An introduction to the philosophy of religion, focusing on the problem of evil: if there is an all-powerful and morally good God, then why is there so much evil in the world? Examination of attempts to reconcile the existence of God with evil by appealing to human free will. Such attempts raise other important philosophical questions: what is free will, and is it compatible with the laws of physics, or with divine providence? Why is freedom valuable? 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PHIL
title: First-Order Logic
description: An introduction to formal logic. Study of the formal deductive systems and semantics for both propositional and predicate logic. Some discussion of metatheory. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PHIL
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3300. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PHIL
title: International Ethics
description: Overview of central ethical questions within the global arena. Topics include international governance, just war, human rights, genocide, global justice, humanitarian intervention, and economic sanctions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PHIL
title: Eastern Philosophy
description: Introduction to Eastern philosophy through the study of philosophical and religious texts. Topics include reality and illusion, knowledge, self, right and wrong, nonattachment, meditation, aesthetics, the meaning of life, and death. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PHIL
title: Environmental Ethics
description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PHIL
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. Recommended preparation: EP&E 215 or a course in political philosophy. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PHYS
title: CLOSED TO FURTHER ENROLLMENTS
description: Seminar that examines the science behind selected advances in modern technology. Focus on the scientific and contextual basis of each advance, as well as the technology's resulting impact on society. Student groups present case studies, with topics developed by the participants in collaboration with the instructor. Intended for nonÃ¢ÂÂscience majors. Enrollment limited. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PHYS
title: CLOSED TO FURTHER ENROLLMENTS
description: Seminar that covers the technology, use, and impact of energy on the environment, climate, security, and the economy. Emphasis on what drives people's choices and the effects of those choices. Prerequisite: a strong background in high school physics, chemistry, and mathematics. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics
description: First part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics and selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles and on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Covers vectors, kinematics, Newtonâs laws of motion, oscillations and waves, gravitation, elasticity, statics, diffusion, fluids, and thermodynamics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Precollege students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. PHYS 150 and 151 are normally taken in sequence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics
description: Second part of a broad introduction, including the traditional parts of classical physics as well as selected topics in modern physics. Emphasis on fundamental principles and on applications drawn from the life sciences and medicine. Covers electricity and magnetism, circuits, light and optics, sound, and modern physics. Suitable for students interested in the biological and medical sciences. Intended primarily for college students. Pre?college students with a background in physics and a solid basis in calculus may apply subject to instructor's approval. Prerequisite: PHYS 150 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S150, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,650. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PHYS
title: General Physics Laboratory
description: A large variety of laboratory experiments, coordinated with the lecture course PHYS S151, and designed to illustrate the physical principles developed in the lectures. For college students only. 1/2 Credit. Tuition $1,650. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers Newtonian mechanics, gravitation, waves, and thermodynamics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.Â May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PHYS
title: University Physics
description: A broad introduction to classical and modern physics for students who have some previous preparation in physics and mathematics. Covers electromagnetism, optics, special relativity, and quantum physics. Calculus at the level of MATH 112 is a prerequisite. May be taken concurrently with MATH 115 and 120 or equivalents.Â May not be taken for credit after PHYS 150, 151, 170, 171. Prerequisite: PHYS 180 or equivalent. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC
title: Intro to Political Philosophy
description: Issues of liberty, equality, and justice considered from within the Western tradition of political philocophy. Readings from Plato, Aristotle, Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Marx, Mill and contemporary authors. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC
title: IntroHumanRightsTheory&Prctice
long_title: Introduction to Human Rights Theory and Practice
description: Introduction to the international human rights regime. Analysis of tools used by actors to promote human rights in the international system. Origins of the regime and contested notions of human rights. Issues include genocide, torture, and the rights of women, children, and sexual minorities. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PLSC
title: CLOSED TO FURTHER ENROLLMENTS
description: The mutual influence of law and politics at the international level. Topics include the sources of international law, the participants, courts, dispute settlement, jurisdiction, and customary law. Readings on foreign policy making, international law, treaties, and international courts from the literature of United Nations bodies and the International Law Commission. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC
title: US Strategy After the Cold War
long_title: U.S. Strategy After the Cold War
description: American grand strategy since the collapse of the Soviet Union. The ability of the United States to project its power around the world. Constraints on and challenges to American power in the international political system. The effect of nuclear weapons on the workings of a unipolar world. The possible emergence of peer competitors in the future. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC
title: Intrnatl HumanRights&Politics
description: International human rights bodies and their implications for international politics. The role of human rights institutions in affording remedies to victims of state abuse. The emergence and exercise of international human rights law, including its nature, mechanisms, and logic. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC
title: The Cold War
description: Examines the Cold War as a struggle for ideological and geopolitical preeminence, tracing its origins, stagnation, and unexpected end from the perspectives of three worlds: capitalist, socialist, and postcolonial. Sources include declassified documents, contemporary fiction and recent secondary reinterpretations, films, and field trips. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC
title: International Ethics
description: Overview of central ethical questions within the global arena. Topics include international governance, just war, human rights, genocide, global justice, humanitarian intervention, and economic sanctions. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PLSC
title: Crime & Punishment
description: Topics in the history, theory, and realities of crime and punishment in the contemporary United States. Focus on various theories of criminal process in light of empirical evidence, the politicization of crime, civil rights issues, psychiatry and the law, abortion, and arguments about prison reform. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC
title: The American Presidency
description: A survey of the historical development of the executive branch of the American national government; an examination of the politics of presidential leadership; and consideration of how the development of the executive branch has affected presidential politics. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PLSC
title: Terrorism, Law, Morality
description: Legal and moral issues in democracies' responses to terrorism. What the term "terrorism" denotes and why and when it is used; U.S. law regarding material support for terrorism; the targeted killing of persons in a global battlefield; how terrorism compares morally to other forms of political violence. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PLSC
title: CANCELLED
description: Responses of Latin American thinkers to fundamental questions in social and political philosophy, from colonial times to the twentieth century. Issues surrounding rights and power, identity, race, culture, and political and economic development. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC
title: Environmental Ethics
description: Questions about human responsibilities for the environment. Wilderness protection, sustainability, preservation of species, the costs of fighting global warming, and humans' right to a healthy environment. Attention to analytical and argumentative skills required in legal and environmental advocacy. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PLSC
title: Lies and Deception
description: Introduction to contemporary philosophical debate about the nature of lies and deception. Definitions of lying and deception, including whether all lies necessarily aim to deceive; moral justifications for lying and deceit and their counterarguments; ways in which the moral arguments against deception of others can apply to self-deception. Recommended preparation: EP&E 215 or a course in political philosophy. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PLSC
title: Cause&EffctInSocialSciResearch
long_title: Cause and Effect in Social Science Research
description: Offered online. Methods used in the social sciences to make inferences about causality and to explain causal relations, including experiments, quantitative and qualitative methods, case studies, and fieldwork. Defining causation; methods for causal attribution; strengths and limitations of real-world research designs; practicalities and logistics of doing research; conceptualization and measurement. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PLSC
title: PoliticsofNationlism&Ethnicity
long_title: The Politics of Nationalism and Ethnicity
description: Study of contemporary work on ethnicity and nationalism from multiple disciplines and analytic traditions. Factors that make ethnicity and nationalism distinctive among social bases of political mobilization. Critical examination of the theory that nationalism is an exclusively modern phenomenon. Nationalism as an attempt to tie powerful organizations to specific territories and individual loyalties. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PORT
title: PortuguesForRomnceLangSpeakrsI
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages
description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S122 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: knowledge of another Romance language. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course Dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: PORT
title: Elem Port Romance Lang Speaker
long_title: Elementary Portuguese for Speakers of Romance Languages II
description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. An intensive elementary course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112 and PORT S352. Prerequisite: knowledge of another romance language.  Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450.  Course Dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese I
description: First four weeks in SÃÂ£o Jose do Rio Preto, SÃÂ£o Paulo, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in Portuguese; an intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Includes visiting the city of SÃÂ£o Paulo and the state of Minas Gerais to provide a broader perspective of modern Brazil. Immersion in the language with exposure and active participation in diverse activities such as visits to industries, trade schools, after-school activities, lectures, and historic tours. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S140. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300.  Course Dates: June 2 - July 27.

subject: PORT
title: Intermediate Portuguese II
description: First four weeks in SÃÂÃÂ£o Jose do Rio Preto, SÃÂÃÂ£o Paulo, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in Portuguese; an intensive intermediate course in Portuguese language emphasizing development of all language skills. Includes visiting the city of SÃÂÃÂ£o Paulo and the state of Minas Gerais to provide a broader perspective of modern Brazil. Immersion in the language with exposure and active participation in diverse activities such as visits to industries, trade schools, after-school activities, lectures, and historic tours. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S130. Prerequisite: PORT 120, 122, 125 or equivalent. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300.  Course Dates: June 2 - July 27.

subject: PORT
title: Introduction to Brazil
description: First three weeks of the course in New Haven, one week in Paraty, last four weeks in Rio de Janeiro. Conducted in English with sessions in Portuguese. An introduction to Brazilian cultural history from 1500 to the present. Essential themes and figures for understanding modern Brazil. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Brazil, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with PORT S112/S122. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: See PORT S112/S122 for tuition. Course Dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: PSYC
title: CLOSED TO FURTHER ENROLLMENTS
description: A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PSYC
title: Introduction to Psychology
description: Offered online. A survey of major psychological approaches to the biological, cognitive, social, and emotional bases of behavior. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PSYC
title: CLOSED TO FURTHER ENROLLMENTS
description: Multidisciplinary approach to studying the nature of the mind. How the fields of philosophy, psychology, neuroscience, computer science, and linguistics contribute methods, theories, and research to addressing questions about how the mind works. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PSYC
title: Human Emotion
description: Introduction to theories of human emotion from diverse fields in psychology. How emotions are perceived, generated, and experienced; culture and gender differences; emotional development over the life span and across species; emotions in social relationships; emotion regulation, including dysregulation in mental illnesses. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PSYC
title: Human Emotion
description: Offered online. Introduction to major discoveries and theories of human emotion. Evolutionary theories of the origins of emotion; culture, sex, and gender influences; emotion and morality; brain basis of emotion; sleeping and feeling; relationship between emotion and thinking; love and relationships; development of emotion; animal vs. human emotion; abnormal emotions in mental illness; and happiness. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PSYC
title: Moralities of Everyday Life
description: Offered online. The modern science of moral thought and moral action explored through disciplines such as cognitive science, social and developmental psychology, neuroscience, behavioral economics, and analytic philosophy. Empathy and compassion in babies and young children; emotional reactions to family, friends, and strangers; the origins of prejudice and bigotry; sexuality, disgust, and purity; punishment, revenge, and forgiveness; the relationship between morality and religion. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PSYC
title: Developmental Psychology
description: Introduction to research and theory on the development and changes in perception, cognition, emotion, and social functioning across the life span. Focus on birth through adulthood. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PSYC
title: Sex, Evolution, & Human Nature
description: How natural selection works and how it can be applied to the study of human psychology. Attention to research methods and findings. Topics include sex and mating, alliances, kinship, visual attention, spatial cognition and memory, and social exchange. May not be taken for credit after PSYC 171b. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PSYC
title: Sex, Evolution, & Human Nature
description: Offered online. How natural selection works and how it can be applied to the study of human psychology. Attention to research methods and findings. Topics include sex and mating, alliances, kinship, visual attention, spatial cognition and memory, and social exchange. May not be taken for credit after PSYC 171b. Enrollment limited to 25 students. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PSYC
title: CANCELLED
description: Study of the major forms of psychopathology that appear in childhood and adult life. Topics include the symptoms of mental disorders; the etiology of disorders from a variety of perspectives (psychological, biological, and sociocultural); and issues pertaining to diagnosis and treatment. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: PSYC
title: Mental LivesofBabiesandAnimals
long_title: Mental Lives of Babies and Animals
description: Offered online. Interdisciplinary exploration of the cognitive, social, and emotional capacities of creatures lacking language and culture. The extent to which our complex psychology is unique to mature humans; the relative richness of a mental life without language or culture. Some attention to particular human populations such as children with autism and adults with language disorders. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: PSYC
title: Autism& Related Disorders
description: Offered online. Survey of current understandings and treatment of autism from infancy through adulthood. Topics include etiology, diagnosis and assessment, treatment and advocacy, and social neuroscience methods. Focus on ways in which research findings are integrated into diagnosis and treatment practices. Prerequisite: PSYC 110 or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For college students only. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Technology fee: $85. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: REL
title: ElemBiblicalHebrew-Sumr Intnsv

subject: REL
title: ElemNTGreek-Summer Intensive

subject: REL
title: Summer Ministry Intensive

subject: REL
title: Ecclesiastical Latin-Intensive

subject: RLST
title: CANCELLED
description: An introduction to the writings of influential thinkers in modern Christian theology. Readings include selections from works by Kant, Schleiermacher, Barth, Rahner, Gutierrez, Tanner, Johnson, and Coakley. The course focuses on understandings of God and of the human person. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: RLST
title: The Bhagavad Gita
description: Examination of the Bhagavad Gita, including the background and meaning of this influential Vaisnava bhakti text. Emphasis on the work's function in the religious fabric of India. Major interpretations of the text during the past two millennia. All readings in translation. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: RLST
title: CANCELLED
description: Approaches religion as a system of symbols, rituals, and beliefs with an eye to classical and contemporary anthropological theory. Addresses broad questions about the roles religion plays in human life in relation to people's conceptions of worldviews and the supernatural. Examines the historical and regional contexts of religious formations around the world and the relationship between religion and modernization. Debates regarding religious violence, secularism, and atheism are also covered. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian I
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 120. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S140 and RUSS S242. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 3 - July 29.

subject: RUSS
title: Second-Year Russian II
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the second year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 120. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S140 and RUSS S242. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 3 - July 29.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian I
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the 5 weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 140. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S151 & RUSS S242. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 3 - July 29.

subject: RUSS
title: Third-Year Russian
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. An intensive "at-home-and-abroad" course featuring language study at the third year level of Russian. Students receive language training during the three weeks in New Haven, developing skills that are then applied during the five weeks in Russia. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board while in Russia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Prerequisite: RUSS 140. Must be taken in conjunction with RUSS S150 and RUSS S242. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 3 - July 29.

subject: RUSS
title: Fourth Year Russian I

subject: RUSS
title: Russian Culture
description: Three weeks in New Haven, five weeks in St. Petersburg. This course explores the cultural history of the imperial Russian capital, founded by Peter the Great in the early eighteenth century as a window on Europe. Since then, the city has been seen to embody all of the contradictions of Russia: East vs. West, imperial grandeur vs. the pathos of the little man, nature vs. civilization, free will vs. fate. The course considers the semiotics of Petersburg through a careful reading of selected literary texts, both prose and poetry, including Pushkin, Gogol, Dostoevsky, Blok, Bely, Gumilev, Akhmatova, Mandelstam, Khlebnikov, Mayakovsky, Kharms, and others, as well as some works of literary and cultural criticism. The classroom sessions are complemented with a rich selection of excursions and tours in and around St.Petersburg. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from St. Petersburg, costs of room and board, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Must be taken in conjunction with either RUSS 130/140 or RUSS S150/151. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see RUSS S130/140 or RUSS S 150/151.  Course Dates: June 3 - July 29.

subject: SAST
title: Bombay:City, SocietyandCulture
description: Offered in Mumbai, India. Students will have the opportunity to study and be in class with local students from St. Xavier's University. Critical engagement with contemporary Indian politics, society, culture and religion through an intensive and immersive study in Mumbai, one of the largest cities in the world. Topics include: urban poverty, urban town planning, housing problems, sanitation, cultural politics, religious and sectarian violence, caste politics, class ghettoization, communal violence, migration, urbanârural divide, Bollywood and popular culture. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from India, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 5.

subject: SAST
title: CANCELLED
description: An exploration of the Himalayan region through film and ethnography. Visual and textual genres of storytelling and narration are used to examine topics such as adventure, caste, education, gender, ritual, and violence. Films and readings are drawn from Bhutan, northern India, Nepal, and Tibet. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: SCIE
title: ScientfcRsrch:Proces&Presntatn
description: This course is intended to provide comprehensive training and support to STARS students engaged in scientific research. Students will be introduced to the scientific process, including hypothesis testing, experimental design, and data interpretation, through lectures, readings, and discussions of the primary scientific literature. Skills development will emphasize the process of discussions for preparing written scientific reports and oral presentations, highlighting effectual communication skills and the ability to interpret and display quantitative and qualitative information. For STARS students only. Course may not be repeated for credit. 1 credit. Tuition $3,300. June 9 - August 9.

subject: SOCY
title: Sex & Gender in Society
description: A sociological approach to the study of sex and gender, focusing on how and why these categories matter for individuals and societies. Topics include the relationship between sex and gender; sex/gender difference and competing explanations for sexual inequality; gender and work; sex and sexuality in society; masculinity, gender, and sports; and feminism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: SOCY
title: Sociology of Crime&Deviance
description: An introduction to sociological approaches to crime and deviance. Review of patterns of illegal activity within society, data sources, and theoretical explanations. Topics include drug use, violence, and white-collar crime. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: SOCY
title: Fndtns of Modern Social Theory
description: Major works of social thought that articulate the core ideas of sociology. Attention to social and historical contexts, conceptual frameworks and methods, and contributions to contemporary social analysis. Writers include Hobbes, Locke, J.S. Mill, Rousseau, Marx, Durkheim, and Weber. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: SOCY
title: Global Public Health
description: Introduction to public health issues and health development processes that are independent of national territorial boundaries but also incorporate the health needs and priorities of individual nation-states. Mechanisms and challenges involved in incorporating the World Health Organization's commitment to primary health care with principles that currently dominate the global public health agenda. Sociological critique of public health interventions. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: SOCY
title: Multiculturalsm&OrderedSociety
description: Is there a link between social identity and crime?  What is the relationship among race, gender, and perceptions of criminality?  What has been the impact of increasing social diversity on forms of social control, crime, and criminal justice policy?  This seminar explores these questions by examining the intersection of multiculturalism, crime, and the criminal justice system.  Students will be introduced to major, relevant criminological and sociological concepts, theories, and debates. Class discussions will address contemporary social problems such as racial profiling, disproportionate punishment, mass incarceration, and unequal justice.  Examples draw principally from the American but also from the British context, providing a comparative perspective. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: SOCY
title: Society&Politicsof NorthAfrica
long_title: Society and Politics of North Africa
description: Offered in Ifrane and Rabat, Morocco. The Maghrib--Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, and Libya--has historically been a critical frontier zone linking Africa, the Middle East, and Europe.  This crossroads remains strategically important with sub-Saharan and North African migration, political Islam, Arab-Berber identity, terrorism and counter-terrorism, the Sahara question, and Mediterranean trade relationships current international concerns.  This course provides a thorough overview of North African history, the legacies of colonialism and nationalism, political systems and opposition, Islam in North Africa, and the Maghrib in the 21st century. Students will also meet with local experts, interact with Moroccan university students, and be able to do optional home stays with Moroccan families. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Morocco, room and board costs in Morocco, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. Tuition $6,400. Course dates: June 1 - July 6.

subject: SOCY
title: Culture of Southeastern Europe
description: Offered in Dubrovnik, Croatia. Multidisciplinary study from antiquity to modernity. Byzantine presence and the remnants of the Roman world; consequences of the schism between Rome and Constantinople; barbarian kingdoms and the medieval city-states; Ottoman incursions and millets; Renaissance and Baroque; beginning of nationalism and modern national integrations; national revolutions, fascism, communism, and postcommunist conflicts; secularization of religion; genocide in post-Yugoslav wars. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Dubrovnik, room and board costs in Croatia, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Must be taken in conjunction with HIST S299. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,200. Course dates: June 30 - August 3.

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish I
description: For students who wish to begin study of the Spanish language. Development of basic skills in understanding, speaking, reading, and writing through a functional approach to the teaching of Spanish grammar. Includes an introduction to the cultures (traditions, art, literature, music) of the Spanish-speaking world. Audiovisual materials are incorporated into class sessions. Conducted in Spanish. To be followed by SPAN S120.  Credit only on completion of SPAN S120. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: SPAN
title: Elementary Spanish ll
description: Further development of understanding, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Class sessions incorporate short authentic texts in Spanish, audiovisual materials, and film. Cultural topics of the Spanish-speaking world (traditions, art, literature, music) are included. Conducted in Spanish. After SPAN S110 or in accordance with placement results. Admits to SPAN 130 or 145. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: SPAN
title: Intermediate Spanish I
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks abroad. Development of proficiency in listening, speaking, reading, and writing through communicative activities rather than as a sequence of linguistic units. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, and videos; presentation of cultural topics. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Spain or South America, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S140 (in Lima CRN: 30186, in Bilbao CRN: 30187, in Quito CRN: 30200) and either S247 (CRN: 30251) in Lima, S248 (CRN: 30190) in Bilbao, or S249 (CRN: 30191) in Quito. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $3,450. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: SPAN
title: Theater and Poetry Workshop
description: Offered in Buenos Aires, Argentina.This course explores the dynamics of figurative and theatrical language through close reading of early and contemporary Spanish and Latin American dramatic texts. The selected plays reflect on the topics of gender, identity, love, politics, torture, and violence. Students participate in an acting workshop and attend live performances of Argentine theater. Prerequisite: SPAN 150 or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Buenos Aires, room and board costs in Argentina, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300.  Course dates: May 25 - June 29.

subject: SPAN
title: Cultural Studies of Peru
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Lima, Peru. The historical, social, and cultural development of Peru from pre-Columbian times to the present. Peruvian history; the culture and character of Peru and of its capital, Lima; architecture, art, gastronomic history, immigration, and ethnicity. Use of authentic Spanish language texts, films, music, and visual arts. Conducted in Spanish. Must be taken concurrently with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 or equivalent. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/140. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: SPAN
title: Spain 1936 to Present
long_title: Spain, 1936 to the Present: History, Literature and Culture
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Bilbao. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Spain from the Civil War to the present. Use of a variety of materials, including literary texts, essays, film, television, music, and visual arts. Classes will be held in the headquarters of the University of Deusto, located opposite the statuary and facing the Guggenheim Museum. Founded in 1886, the university continues to be one of the most important institutions of higher education of the Basque Country and Spain. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Bilbao, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/140. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: SPAN
title: Ecuador Pre-Columbian to Pres
long_title: Ecuador from Pre-Columbian Times to Present
description: Four weeks in New Haven, four weeks in Quito. Analysis and discussion of the historical, social, and cultural development of Ecuador from Pre-Columbian times to the present. Presented through a variety of materials (literary texts, essays, films, music, visual arts). Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Quito, costs of room and board, and all other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Must be taken in conjunction with SPAN S130 and S140. Prerequisite: SPAN 120 (Elementary Spanish II) or equivalent. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 1 Credit. Tuition: see SPAN S130/S140. Course dates: June 3 - July 27.

subject: STCY
title: Intro to the Study of the City
long_title: Introduction to the Study of the City
description: An examination of forces shaping American cities and strategies for dealing with them. Topics include housing, commercial development, parks, zoning, urban renewal, landmark preservation, new towns, and suburbs. Includes games, simulated problems, fieldwork, lectures, and discussion as well as field trips in New Haven and to New York City. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili I
description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S140. Prerequisite: SWAH 120b (Elementary Kiswahili II) or equivalent. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu or visit the Yale Summer Session website. Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: SWAH
title: Intermediate Kiswahili II
description: Offered at the Swahili Resource Centre in Mombasa, Kenya. Refinement of students' speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills. Prepares students for further work in literary, language, and cultural studies as well as for a functional use of Kiswahili. Study of structure and vocabulary is based on a variety of texts from traditional and popular culture. Emphasis on command of idiomatic usage and stylistic nuance. Must be taken in conjunction with SWAH S130. Prerequisite: SWAH S130 (Intermediate Kiswahili I) or equivalent. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. Additional costs: $2,500 room and board in Kenya. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Mombasa, and any other expenses beyond tuition. For further information contact the instructor at 203.432.9902 or at ann.biersteker@yale.edu or visit the Yale Summer Session website. Please also see www.yale.edu/macmillan/african. 1 1/2 Credits. Tuition $2,500. Course dates: June 1 - July 27.

subject: SWAH
title: Advanced Kiswahili
description: Offered in Mombasa, Kenya. Development of fluency through readings and discussions on contemporary topics in Kiswahili, including its origins and spread to different parts of Eastern and Central Africa. The role of Kiswahili in addressing issues such as health and the environment. Introduction to literary criticism in Kiswahili. Materials include Kiswahili oral literature, prose, poetry, and plays, as well as texts drawn from popular and political culture. Prerequisite: SWAH 140b or equivalent. Students are responsible for all travel expenses to and from Kenya, room and board costs, and any other expenses beyond tuition. Application deadline: March 1. Enrollment limited. For further information visit the Yale Summer Session website. 2 Credits. Tuition $5,000. Course dates: June 1 - July 13.

subject: THST
title: CANCELLED
long_title: The Tragic Hero in Greek Drama
description: Introduction to the construction and performance of heroism in Greek tragic drama, with close reading of selected plays in translation. Focus on the sagas of the House of Atreus and Oedipus. Defining the tragic hero; the tragic flaw; characterization and stagecraft; playwrights' responses to the Homeric hero; modern responses to Greek tragedy. Includes screenings of film adaptations of the plays. 1 Credit. Tuition: $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: THST
title: CANCELLED
description: Global exploration of embodied ritual performance in Islam. Case studies range from ceremonies of the Mevlevi dervishes in Turkey to activist art in the context of U.S. detention and deportation of Muslims after 9/11. Development of practical skills in ethnographic research. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: THST
title: CANCELLED
description: In-depth reading and discussion of major twentieth-century American playwrights, including Eugene O'Neill, Thornton Wilder, Zora Neale Hurston, Tennessee Williams, Arthur Miller, Edward Albee, David Mamet, and Suzan-Lori Parks. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: WGSS
title: Sex and Gender in Society
description: A sociological approach to the study of sex and gender, focusing on how and why these categories matter for individuals and societies. Topics include the relationship between sex and gender; sex/gender difference and competing explanations for sexual inequality; gender and work; sex and sexuality in society; masculinity, gender, and sports; and feminism. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.

subject: WGSS
title: CLOSED TO FURTHER ENROLLMENTS
description: Interdisciplinary exploration of the gendering of food production, preparation, and consumption in cross-cultural perspective. Topics include agricultural practices, cooking, pasteurization, kitchen technology, food storage, home economics, hunger, anorexia, breast-feeding, meals, and ethnic identity. Class visits to Peabody Museum, Beinecke Library, Yale Farm, and Yale University Art Gallery. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session B: July 8 - August 9.

subject: WGSS
title: Gender in Science and Medicine
description: Scientific and medical ideas about the natural world and the body have long been influenced by concepts of gender, even as expectations regarding gender have been shaped by scientific theories. Students will explore the historical relationship between gender and science, medicine, and technology in Western society, from the medieval and early modern period through to contemporary American debates. Students will analyze the relationship between science, medicine, and gender in order to gain historical insights and a critical perspective with regard to the structure of scientific and medical practice. Class visits to the Medical Historical Library and Peabody Museum expected. 1 Credit. Tuition $3,300. Session A: June 3 - July 5.
